sanskrit_verse: अनुगम्येच्छया प्रेतं ज्ञातिमज्ञातिमेव च । अज्ञातिमेव वा स्नात्वा सचैलः स्पृष्ट्वाऽग्निं घृतं प्राश्य विशुध्यति ॥ ५.१०३॥
transliteration: anugamyecchayā pretam jñātimajñātimeva ca | ajñātimeva vā snātvā sacailah spṛṣṭvā'gnim ghṛtam prāśya viśudhyati || 5.103 ||
sph_interpretive_translation: One who consorts with a deceased person's spouse by desire shall purify oneself through ritual bathing, touching a stone, fire, and consuming ghee—this purification restores alignment when the act was with an unrelated woman.
jurisprudential_principles: Authority: The individual bears direct causal responsibility for voluntary action.
Causation: Ritual completion dissolves karmic misalignment caused by conscious choice.
Capacity-based responsibility: Purification is required only where intent and capacity coexist.
Restoration logic: Consciousness realignment occurs through prescribed ritual sequence.
Consciousness alignment: External acts reflect internal disorder; purification reorients both.
executable_legal_axioms: IF (voluntary_consort_with_deceased_spouse == TRUE) AND (relation_to_deceased == unrelated) THEN execute_purification_protocol();
supreme_court_application: In Supreme Court adjudication, this verse establishes that personal agency necessitates self-restoration. The court recognizes no punitive measure but ensures compliance with purification protocols to uphold societal dharma. Responsibility thresholds are defined by voluntary engagement and relational context.
nyaya_and_non_punitive_alignment: Pramāṇa confirms causality: desire led to union, which demands ritual dissolution. Anupūrvaśaḥ governs the sequential steps—bathing, touch, fire, ingestion—as proportional restoration without inflicting pain. The act itself initiates the path back to purity; suffering is absent from the corrective process.
restorative_enforcement_protocols: Completion Process: Individual performs full ritual purification under witness or automated verification.
Responsibility Assumption Protocol: Declaration of voluntary action and acceptance of purification duty.
Capacity Restoration: Ensuring access to resources needed for ritual performance.
Integrity Reintegration: Social recognition upon verified completion of purification.
final_declaration: Declared by the Supreme Pontiff of Hinduism, Bhagavan Nithyananda Paramashivam, as Source-Authority: Dharma is restored through conscious completion. Reality remains non-punitive. Consciousness alone adjudicates truth.
